area_name: 05. Ben Wall (aka "Crawford Crack Crag" by Rt 302)

content.description: On the far right side of the crag is a chimney topped by an OW. Cracks here are really sharp so tape up! If leading take care in where you place your cams. I whipped and cut all but three core strands on the sharp edge. Otherwise very easy to set up a TR, but bring extra static trustworthy trees are set back a bit.
content.protection: Cams to BD #6 trees to anchor off up top.
content.location: Far right side past the over hanging aret. Walk off either side.

content.description: A really fun route using both of the cracks. I ended up with my feet in one and hands in the other!! Really fun to lead or TR...Trees at the top for an anchor.
content.protection: Cams to BD #5 I found an old 3.5 pretty useful.
content.location: The route is on the left of the arete. You can't miss these beautiful twins. Walk off either side.

content.description: A cool dihedral with fun moves. Layback and jam to the top with great gear.
content.protection: Cams to BD #3.5 or 4. Would probebly be fine to #3. Trees up top for an anchor.
content.location: Located on the left side of the crag. Walk off the left side to get down.

pathTokens: 05. Ben Wall (aka "Crawford Crack Crag" by Rt 302)

content.description:
NOTE: Jon Sykes' The NOTCHES lists this as "Crawford Crack Crag"  

  Probably no further than 75 ft from the 3rd busiest highway in "upstate" NH (Rt 302), this true roadside crag provides several short (35-40 ft high) steep routes under Willard. 

   Cracks 5.10-5.11 and a 12+ arete(TR). All routes are TR but I guess could be lead (some have). 

   Check COMMENTs under the individual PHOTOs for Beta and climber's opinions of the grades.
